missions.name: Voyager 1
missions.description: NASA's Voyager 1 is the first human-made object to venture into interstellar space. Launched in 1977, the spacecraft visited Jupiter and Saturn before continuing its journey beyond our solar system.

missions.name: Voyager 2
missions.description: Voyager 2 is the only spacecraft to have visited all four gas giant planets â€” Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune. It is currently exploring the outermost reaches of the heliosphere.

missions.name: New Horizons
missions.description: New Horizons is a NASA mission to study Pluto, its moons, and other objects in the Kuiper Belt. In 2015, it became the first spacecraft to visit Pluto, revealing stunning details about the dwarf planet.

missions.name: Juno
missions.description: Juno is studying Jupiter from a polar orbit to understand the planet's origin and evolution, looking at its gravity field, magnetic field, and polar magnetosphere.

missions.name: James Webb Space Telescope
missions.description: The James Webb Space Telescope is the largest, most powerful space telescope ever built, designed to peer deeper into the universe's past than ever before.

missions.name: DART
missions.description: The Double Asteroid Redirection Test (DART) was a spacecraft designed to test whether a kinetic impact could deflect an asteroid. It successfully impacted the asteroid Dimorphos in 2022.

missions.name: Parker Solar Probe
missions.description: The Parker Solar Probe is studying the Sun's outer corona to improve our understanding of the solar wind and space weather.

missions.name: OSIRIS-REx
missions.description: The OSIRIS-REx mission collected samples from the asteroid Bennu and delivered them back to Earth in 2023.

celestialObjects.name: Sun
celestialObjects.description: The Sun is the star at the center of our Solar System, a nearly perfect sphere of hot plasma. It is the most important source of energy for life on Earth.

celestialObjects.name: Mercury
celestialObjects.description: Mercury is the smallest planet in our Solar System and the closest to the Sun, with a highly eccentric orbit and very high temperatures.

celestialObjects.name: Venus
celestialObjects.description: Venus is the second planet from the Sun and Earth's closest planetary neighbor, with a thick atmosphere trapping heat in a runaway greenhouse effect.

celestialObjects.name: Earth
celestialObjects.description: Earth is the third planet from the Sun and the only known astronomical object to harbor life, with liquid water on its surface and a protective atmosphere.

celestialObjects.name: Mars
celestialObjects.description: Mars is the fourth planet from the Sun, often called the 'Red Planet' due to its reddish appearance caused by iron oxide on its surface.

celestialObjects.name: Jupiter
celestialObjects.description: Jupiter is the fifth planet from the Sun and the largest in our Solar System, composed mainly of hydrogen and helium, with distinct cloud bands and the Great Red Spot.

celestialObjects.name: Saturn
celestialObjects.description: Saturn is the sixth planet from the Sun, known for its prominent ring system made up of ice particles, rocky debris, and dust.

celestialObjects.name: Uranus
celestialObjects.description: Uranus is the seventh planet from the Sun, an ice giant with a tilted rotation axis that causes it to rotate on its side.

celestialObjects.name: Neptune
celestialObjects.description: Neptune is the eighth and farthest known planet from the Sun, a dark, cold, and windy ice giant with the strongest winds in the Solar System.

celestialObjects.name: Pluto
celestialObjects.description: Pluto is a dwarf planet in the Kuiper belt, a ring of bodies beyond Neptune. It was discovered in 1930 and was considered the ninth planet until 2006.
